Alternatively, to be safer, variables like c and top must not be keywords. 'Top' is okay. Assuming the variable names are fine, perhaps:

Rewriting with variable names p and q:

program atcoder_ABC120_C
    implicit none
    integer, parameter :: max_len = 100000
    character(len=max_len) :: x
    integer :: i, c, top =0, nchars
    character(len=1), dimension(:), allocatable :: stack
    character(len=1) :: p, q 

    ! Read input
    read(*, '(a)', advance='no') x
    nchars = len_trim(x)

    allocate( stack(nchars) )

    c =0 do i =1, nchars

        top = top +1
        stack(top) = x(i:i) inner_loop: do
            if (top <=1) exit inner_loop 

            p = stack(top)
            top = top -1
            q = stack(top)
            top = top -1 

            if ( (p == '0' .and. q == '1') .or. (p == '1' .and. q == '0') ) then
                c = c +1 
                cycle inner_loop 
            else 
                ! Push back q and p 
                top = top +1
                stack(top) = q
                top = top +1
                stack(top) = p 

                exit inner_loop
            endif 
        end do inner_loop 

    end do 

    print*, c *2 

    deallocate(stack)
end program atcoder_ABC120_C 

Wait but in the else block, when pushing back, the first popped is p (top of stack), then q was the previous.

Now, handling the code's variables:

Another thing to note is that in Fortran, array indices start at 1. The stack is dimensioned from 1 to nchars (since allocated as stack(nchars)), but in the code above, the initial top =0. 

Wait, the stack array allocation is to nchars, so the indices go from 1 up. So pushing starts at 1.

Yes, that's correct.

Now, the final code in Fortran would look like:

So putting it all together:

program atcoder_ABC120_C
    implicit none
    integer, parameter :: max_len = 100000
    character(len=max_len) :: x
    integer :: i, c, top, nchars
    character(len=1), dimension(:), allocatable :: stack
    character(len=1) :: pt, qt  ! renamed variables to prevent conflicts with F90 keywords like 'p' could conflict?

    read(*, '(a)') x
    nchars = len_trim(x)
    allocate(stack(nchars))
    top = 0
    c = 0

    do i = 1, nchars
        top = top + 1
        stack(top) = x(i:i)

        inner_loop: do
            if (top <= 1) exit inner_loop
            pt = stack(top)
            top = top -1
            qt = stack(top)
            top = top -1

            if ( (pt == '0' .and. qt == '1') .or. (pt == '1' .and. qt == '0') ) then
                c = c +1
                ! continue the loop since stack may now have more elements
                cycle inner_loop
            else
                ! push back qt and pt
                top = top +1
                stack(top) = qt
                top = top +1
                stack(top) = pt
                exit inner_loop
            end if
        end do inner_loop
    end do

    print*, c *2
    deallocate(stack)

end program atcoder_ABC120_C

Wait, I had to avoid using 'p' as a variable since in some cases, Fortran may not like variable names that could clash with Fortran internal functions, so used 'pt' and 'qt'.

Testing this code step by step.

In Fortran, some keywords are IF, DO, ELSE, etc., but as long as variable names aren't those, it's okay. 

So perhaps just p and q work.

Alternatively, to be safer, variables like c and top must not be keywords. 'Top' is okay.

Assuming the variable names are fine, perhaps:

Rewriting with variable names p and q:

program atcoder_ABC120_C
    implicit none
    integer, parameter :: max_len = 100000
    character(len=max_len) :: x
    integer :: i, c, top =0, nchars
    character(len=1), dimension(:), allocatable :: stack
    character(len=1) :: p, q 

    ! Read input
    read(*, '(a)', advance='no') x
    nchars = len_trim(x)

    allocate( stack(nchars) )

    c =0 

    do i =1, nchars

        top = top +1
        stack(top) = x(i:i)

        inner_loop: do
            if (top <=1) exit inner_loop 

            p = stack(top)
            top = top -1
            q = stack(top)
            top = top -1 

            if ( (p == '0' .and. q == '1') .or. (p == '1' .and. q == '0') ) then
                c = c +1 
                cycle inner_loop 
            else 
                ! Push back q and p 
                top = top +1
                stack(top) = q
                top = top +1
                stack(top) = p 

                exit inner_loop
            endif 
        end do inner_loop 

    end do 

    print*, c *2 

    deallocate(stack)
end program atcoder_ABC120_C 

Wait but in the else block, when pushing back, the first popped is p (top of stack), then q was the previous. 

When we push back, first push q (because after popping p (top) first, then q. So the order should be: push q back first (to previous's current top's below), then push p on top of it. 

Wait according to the steps:

After pops, the top had been:

Initial top before pops was say T. 

Popping p: 

p = stack(T) 

top becomes T-1 

then q = stack(T-1)

top becomes T-2 

So now, the current top is T-2 

So after the pops, the stack is now T-2 

When pushing back, first set top = T-2 +1 = T-1. 

stack(T-1) = q → next top becomes T-1. 

Then top becomes T (T-1 +1 = T), set stack(T) = P → 

so the stack now has q at T-1 and p at T.

 Thus, the order is correct. 

Therefore the code should be correct.

Now, last thing: when reading the input. In Fortran, when you read a string with read(*, '(a)') x, it reads until end of record (which is end of line in most cases unless the input is unformatted). 

However, to make sure that trailing spaces are not included, it's better to use len_trim. 

I think this should handle it.

Another point: the input may be too long for the max_len of 1e5. Well, considering the problem constraints, that's acceptable as per problem's expectation.

Thus, the Fortran code should work as required.
